hint.text:
find the \(n^{th}\) term and use
Sum of an A.P. = \(\frac n2(2a+(n-1)d)\)
Then find \(S_n\) using following identities
\(\sum_1^n(n)=\frac{n(n+1)}{2}\)
\(\sum_1^n(n^2)=\frac{n(n+1)(2n+1)}{6}\)
\(\sum_1^n(n^3)=\frac{\left(n(n+1)\right)^2}{4}\)

solution.text:
The \(n^{th}\) term of the given series is the sum of n terms of an A.P.
i.e.
\(a_n=S_n^l\)
Where, \(S_n^l\) = sum of n terms of the A.P.
\(_{p}_ , _{{p+q}}_ , _{{p+2*q}}_ , _{{p+3*q}}_ , ...\)
i.e.
\(a_n= \frac n2(2a+(n-1)d)\)
where, a and d are the first term and common difference of the A.P. mentioned above
\(a_n= \frac d2 n^2 + (a-\frac d2)n\)
\(a_n= _{{q/2}}_ n^2 + _{{p-(q/2)}}_n\)
now summing this from 1 to n we will get the sum
\(S_n=\sum_1^n a_n= \sum_1^n(_{{q/2}}_ n^2 + _{{p-(q/2)}}_n)\)
\(S_n=_{{q/2}}_\sum_1^n(n^2)+_{{p-(q/2)}}_\sum_1^n(n)\) .....(1)
also we know
\(\sum_1^n(1)=n\)
\(\sum_1^n(n)=\frac{n(n+1)}{2}\)
\(\sum_1^n(n^2)=\frac{n(n+1)(2n+1)}{6}\)
substitution this in equation (1), we will get
\(S_n=_{{q/2}}_\frac{n(n+1)(2n+1)}{6}+_{{p-(q/2)}}_\frac{n(n+1)}{2}\)
Now putting n=_{s}_
\(S_ {_{s}_}=_{{q/2}}_\frac{_{{s*(s+1)*(2*s+1)}}_}{6}+_{{p-(q/2)}}_\frac{_{{s*(s+1)}}_}{2}\)
\(S_ {_{s}_}=_{{(q*s*(s+1)*(2*s+1))/12}}_+_{{((p-(q/2))*s*(s+1))/2}}_\)
\(S_ {_{s}_}=_{{((q*s*(s+1)*(2*s+1))/12)+(((p-(q/2))*s*(s+1))/2)}}_\)
